data.title: Dick Van Dyke (b. 1920s)

data.text:
Born 1920s.

Ancestors

[children unknown]

Profile last modified 12 Mar 2024 | Created 2 Mar 2012

This page has been accessed 7,415 times.

Biography

Dick Van Dyke is an American actor, comedian, writer, singer, dancer, and producer with a career spanning seven decades.

Dick was born on 13 Dec 1925 in West Plains, Howell, Missouri, USA.[1][1][2][3] He was the son of Loren Wayne Van Dyke and Hazel Vorice McCord. The family had moved to Danville, Vermillion, Illinois at the time of the 1930 US Census, and the family was still there in 1935. Cookie Van Dyke owned a local grocery store. Dick was raised as a Presbyterian and attended Immanuel Presbyterian Church in Danville, IL. His Sunday school teacher was his mother's first cousin and best friend Frances McCord Kesler. This church is now known as the Kathryn Randolph Theater in Danville and the new church home is the First Presbyterian Church of Danville. [1][3]

By 1940, they Van Dykes had moved to Crawfordsville, Montgomery, Indiana.[3]

In 1942, Dick was serving in the US Army in their contributions to World War II.

Dick married Marjorie T Willet in 1948 in the USA on a game show as they couldn't afford the cost of a real wedding. Willet was from Danville and the two had known each other growing up. When Dick when come to court Margie at her home, a local football player from Danville High School who also liked her would yell at him from the front yard to leave the house so he (Dick) would run out the back door. They divorced in 1984 and he then was with actress Michelle Triola Marvin until her death from cancer in 2009. Dick and Margie had four children together, Chris, Barry, Stacey and Carrie Beth. Margie did a lot of the raising of the children as Dick was away a lot in Hollywood with his career. [3]

In 1954, Dick was listed in public records as residing in Atlanta, De Kalb, Georgia.[4]

He was in California from 1983 (at least) onward, being listed in Venice, Los Angeles in 1983 and in Malibu Beach in 2003, in public records.[5][2]

Dick married Arlene Silver on 29 Feb 2012 in the USA.
